sources: Ohio Department of Natural Resources Division of Wildlife
Indiana Department of Natural Resources Division of Fish & Wildlife
notes: Regulations are subject to change. Always verify with official state agencies before fishing.
Great Lakes regulations often differ from inland water regulations.
Some regulations vary by specific lake, zone, or management area.
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations.
Tribal fishing rights may apply in certain waters.

license_requirements.notes: Lake Erie fishing permit required for fishing in Lake Erie and its tributaries. Three lines permitted in Lake Erie waters.

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 walleye, saugeye, and sauger combined. Minimum size applies most of regulation period.
species.special_regulations: Lake Erie has variable daily limits announced in late April. Size and bag limits may change May-February.
species.geographic_restrictions: Lake Erie regulations differ from inland waters

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Erie: West Zone 30, Central Zone 10, East Zone 30 (March 1 - April 30). Limits may change May-February.
species.special_regulations: Variable zonal limits. Updates announced in late April for May-February period.
species.geographic_restrictions: Lake Erie divided into West, Central, and East zones

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 bass total (all black bass species combined)
5 bass total (all black bass species combined)
2 fish (March 1-May 15); 5 fish (May 16-Aug 31); 2 fish (Sept 1-Feb 28)
species.special_regulations: Brook trout prohibited from Ashtabula, Chagrin, Conneaut, and Grand rivers and tributaries. Minimum size 12 inches.

species.bag_limit_notes: No minimum size or daily limit
species.special_regulations: Applies to striped bass, hybrid striped bass, and white bass

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 fish daily, only 1 may exceed 28 inches
30 crappie total (black and white crappie combined)
30 crappie total (black and white crappie combined)
Check specific water body regulations
Check specific water body regulations
species.special_regulations: Water-specific size and bag limits. Some waters have minimum size requirements.

license_requirements.notes: All anglers 17 years and older must have a valid Michigan fishing license. See Fisheries Orders for full legal descriptions.

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Erie: limits updated annually on May 1. Other Great Lakes: varies by specific lake and zone.
species.special_regulations: Walleye bag limits updated each year on May 1 for the Great Lakes. Minimum size 13 inches statewide.
species.geographic_restrictions: Regulations vary by Great Lake and management zone

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Gogebic: 25 perch, no more than 5 over 12 inches. Other waters may vary.
species.special_regulations: Some waters have protected slot limits for larger perch

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 bass total (largemouth and smallmouth combined)
5 bass total (largemouth and smallmouth combined)
Great Lakes and connecting waters: minimum 10 inches. Specific bag limits vary by lake.
species.special_regulations: Minimum size 10 inches in Great Lakes

species.bag_limit_notes: Great Lakes: minimum 10 inches. Combined trout and salmon limits apply.
Great Lakes: minimum 10 inches. Combined trout and salmon limits apply.
Great Lakes: minimum 10 inches. Some Type 3 and Type 4 streams no longer have 20-inch minimum (2025 update).
species.special_regulations: 2025 regulation changes: some streams no longer have 20-inch minimum. Daily possession limit remains 1 on many streams.
species.geographic_restrictions: Regulations vary by Great Lake and tributary

species.bag_limit_notes: 1 fish daily. Thornapple Lake and Lake Hudson now have 50-inch minimum (new for 2025).
species.special_regulations: New 2025: 50-inch minimum on Thornapple Lake (Barry/Eaton counties) and Lake Hudson (Lenawee County)

species.bag_limit_notes: Varies by water body. Some waters have special regulations.
25 crappie combined (black and white)
25 crappie combined (black and white)

license_requirements.notes: Anglers must carry a paper copy of license/stamps while fishing on Lake Michigan, Lake Superior, and boundary waters. Trout/salmon stamp required for Great Lakes trout and salmon.

species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide daily bag limit of 3 on inland waters. Great Lakes may have different limits.
species.geographic_restrictions: Regulations vary by water body and Great Lake

species.bag_limit_notes: Typically 25 panfish per day (perch included in panfish aggregate)
species.geographic_restrictions: Regulations may vary by Great Lake

species.bag_limit_notes: Generally 5 bass combined. Check county-specific regulations.
species.special_regulations: Special regulations apply to many waters

species.bag_limit_notes: Generally 5 bass combined. Check county-specific regulations.
species.special_regulations: Special regulations apply to many waters

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Superior tributaries: 5 trout and salmon total, season May 3, 2025 - March 1, 2026
species.special_regulations: Green Bay tributaries season: May 3, 2025 - March 1, 2026
species.geographic_restrictions: Different seasons for main lakes vs tributaries

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 trout and salmon combined on tributaries
5 trout and salmon combined on tributaries
Lake Superior streams: May 3, 2025 - Sept 30, 2025, 5 total trout/salmon, only 1 rainbow trout, only 2 brown trout over 15 inches
species.special_regulations: Extended Lake Superior tributaries season available. Trout/salmon stamp required.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different regulations for streams vs main lakes

species.bag_limit_notes: 1 fish, must be at least 40 inches
species.season_open: Northern Zone: May 24, 2025; Southern Zone: May 3, 2025
species.special_regulations: Different opening dates for Northern and Southern zones

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 pike of any length
25 panfish total (all panfish species combined)
25 panfish total (all panfish species combined)

license_requirements.notes: Valid Indiana fishing license required. Check Indiana DNR for specific Lake Michigan regulations.

species.bag_limit_notes: Check Lake Michigan specific regulations on Indiana DNR website
species.special_regulations: Lake Michigan may have specific regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: 15 perch daily limit in Indiana waters of Lake Michigan
Check for specific Lake Michigan regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: Minimum size 14 inches for trout and salmon in Lake Michigan
1 fish daily, 36-inch minimum
2 fish daily, 30-inch minimum

license_requirements.notes: Valid Illinois fishing license required. Lake Michigan Salmon Stamp required for salmon and trout fishing.

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 walleye, sauger, or hybrid combined. 14-inch minimum except Mississippi River, Wabash River, or site-specific exceptions.
15 perch daily in combined waters of Lake Michigan, Calumet River, and Chicago River (including North Branch, South Branch, North Shore Channel)
12-inch minimum size statewide
12-inch minimum size statewide
5 trout or salmon, singly or in aggregate
species.season_closed: October 1 - 3rd Saturday in October; March 15 - 1st Saturday in April
species.special_regulations: Possession prohibited during closed periods for trout caught during those periods. Lake Michigan Salmon Stamp required.

species.bag_limit_notes: 1 fish daily, 36-inch minimum (includes tiger muskie)
3 fish daily, 24-inch minimum (no minimum in Mississippi River)
10 crappie combined (white, black, or hybrid), 10-inch minimum
10 crappie combined (white, black, or hybrid), 10-inch minimum

species.bag_limit_daily: No limit 13-28 inches; 1 fish over 28 inches
species.bag_limit_notes: No harvest limit for 13-28 inch fish; only 1 fish over 28 inches daily

license_requirements.notes: Lake Superior anglers must possess Minnesota angling license and Minnesota trout/salmon stamp validation. Check Minnesota DNR for complete regulations.

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 walleye and sauger in aggregate. Minimum size typically 15 inches but varies by zone and water body.
species.special_regulations: Regulations vary significantly by water body and zone

species.bag_limit_notes: Check specific water body regulations. Generally included in panfish limits.
6 bass combined (largemouth and smallmouth)
species.special_regulations: Zone-specific regulations. Some areas have catch-and-release only periods.
species.geographic_restrictions: Northeast Zone vs statewide regulations differ

species.bag_limit_notes: 6 bass combined (largemouth and smallmouth). Catch-and-release only May 10-23, 2025 (except Northeast Zone).
species.special_regulations: Statewide catch-and-release only May 10-23, 2025 (except Northeast Zone)

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Superior: specific regulations apply. Trout/salmon stamp required.
species.special_regulations: Lake Superior anglers must have trout/salmon stamp

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Superior regulations apply. Trout/salmon stamp required.
species.special_regulations: Trout/salmon stamp validation required for Lake Superior

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Superior regulations apply. Trout/salmon stamp required.
species.special_regulations: Trout/salmon stamp validation required for Lake Superior

species.bag_limit_notes: Lake Superior streams: check stream-specific regulations. Trout/salmon stamp required.
species.special_regulations: Trout/salmon stamp required. Lake Superior tributary regulations vary.
species.geographic_restrictions: Lake Superior streams and main lake

species.bag_limit_notes: 1 fish, 54-inch minimum statewide. Metro lakes (Hennepin, Ramsey, Dakota, Carver, Scott, Washington counties) have 40-inch minimum.
species.special_regulations: Reduced 40-inch minimum in metro lakes. Season June 7 - December 1.
species.geographic_restrictions: Metro counties have different minimum size (40 inches vs 54 inches)

species.bag_limit_notes: Maximum 10 fish possession. Specific size and bag limits vary by zone (Northeast, North-central, Southern).
species.special_regulations: Three zones with different regulations. Angling and spearing have separate regulations.
species.geographic_restrictions: Northeast, North-central, and Southern zones each have specific regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: Typically 5 in many standard waters. Special regulations apply to specific lakes.
Typically 5 in many standard waters. Special regulations apply to specific lakes.
5 fish possession limit, only 1 over 24 inches
2 fish possession limit, only 1 over 24 inches
Typically 5 in many standard waters. Some lakes have different daily limits.
30 in aggregate with white bass (new statewide regulation)
4 fish possession limit (new statewide regulation)
15 fish possession limit for fish over 7 inches (new statewide regulation)
species.special_regulations: New statewide regulation for 2025-2026. Must be over 7 inches.

great_lakes_specific_notes: Great Lakes regulations are complex and often differ from inland water regulations
Interstate waters may have reciprocal agreements or require licenses from both states
Tribal waters may have different regulations and may require tribal permits
Lake Erie has coordinated multi-state management for walleye and yellow perch
Lake Michigan salmon and trout seasons and bag limits are coordinated across bordering states
Lake Superior regulations often require special stamps or validations for trout and salmon
data_gaps: Some water-specific regulations not fully detailed
Tribal waters and treaty waters not comprehensively covered
Special management zones may have additional restrictions
Emergency orders and in-season adjustments not included
Some rare or less common species not included
recommendations: Always verify current regulations before fishing - regulations change annually
Check for emergency orders and proclamations on state DNR websites
Download state-specific fishing apps for real-time regulation updates
Understand the difference between bag limits, possession limits, and size limits
Know proper fish measurement techniques (total length vs fork length)
Be aware of Great Lakes-specific gear restrictions
Understand interstate waters and reciprocal agreements
Respect tribal fishing rights and treaty waters

Ohio.agency: Ohio Department of Natural Resources Division of Wildlife

Indiana.agency: Indiana Department of Natural Resources Division of Fish & Wildlife

important_definitions.bag_limit_daily: The maximum number of fish of a species that may be taken in one day
important_definitions.possession_limit: The maximum number of fish that may be in possession at any time (often 2x daily bag limit)
important_definitions.total_length: Measurement from tip of snout to tip of tail in natural position
important_definitions.fork_length: Measurement from tip of snout to fork in tail
important_definitions.slot_limit: A range of sizes that must be released; fish below minimum and above maximum may be kept
important_definitions.aggregate_limit: Combined limit for multiple species counted together
important_definitions.protected_slot: A size range where fish must be released to protect spawning stock
